sn3.13:1.1.comm: This Sutta presents what is probably the world’s first weight loss diet.

sn3.13:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo doṇapākakuraṃ bhuñjati.
sn3.13:1.2.eng: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala used to eat boiled rice by the bucketful.
sn3.13:1.2.comm: A doṇa (“bucketful”) was a wooden trough to receive the filtered Soma (Rig Veda 4.32.17). In the Arthaśāstra it measures feed for horses (2.30.12) and elephants (2.15.50). One doṇa was the monthly allotment of grain for a servant (Manu 7.126). Olivelle estimates it at 5 liters or 9.6 kg (King, Governance, and Law, appendix 2, pg. 458). | The use of present tense (bhuñjati) here indicates that it is an ongoing situation, not just a single large meal (compare the aorist in the previous Sutta).

sn3.13:1.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhuttāvī mahassāsī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn3.13:1.3.eng: Then after eating King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, huffing and puffing. He bowed and sat down to one side.

sn3.13:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhuttāviṃ mahassāsiṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn3.13:2.1.eng: Then, knowing that King Pasenadi was huffing and puffing after eating, on that occasion the Buddha spoke this verse:

sn3.13:3.3.comm: For vedanā as “discomfort”, compare the stock reflection on eating (SN 35.120:4.3).

sn3.13:3.4.eng: and he ages slowly, taking care of his life.”

sn3.13:4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sudassano māṇavo rañño pasenadissa kosalassa piṭṭhito ṭhito hoti.
sn3.13:4.1.eng: Now at that time the student Sudassana was standing behind the king.
sn3.13:4.1.comm: This Vedic student attending the king is otherwise unknown.

sn3.13:4.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo sudassanaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantesi:

sn3.13:4.3.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, tāta sudassana, bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā mama bhattābhihāre bhattābhihāre bhāsa.
sn3.13:4.3.eng: “Please, dear Sudassana, memorize this verse in the Buddha’s presence and recite it to me whenever I am served a meal.
sn3.13:4.3.comm: This passages well illustrates the meaning of pariyāpuṇāti as “memorize”.

sn3.13:4.4.pli: Ahañca te devasikaṃ kahāpaṇasataṃ kahāpaṇasataṃ niccaṃ bhikkhaṃ pavattayissāmī”ti.
sn3.13:4.4.eng: I’ll set up a regular daily allowance of a hundred dollars for you.”
sn3.13:4.4.comm: Niccabhikkhā at Ja 398:4.1 refers to the daily offering of food to a yakkha. Here and at MN 94:33.1 it refers to money.

sn3.13:4.5.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho sudassano māṇavo rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa bhattābhihāre sudaṃ bhāsati:
sn3.13:4.5.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Sudassana. He memorized that verse in the Buddha’s presence, and then whenever the king was served a meal he would repeat it:

sn3.13:5.4.eng: and he ages slowly, taking care of his life.”

sn3.13:6.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo anupubbena nāḷikodanaparamatāya saṇṭhāsi.
sn3.13:6.1.eng: Then the king gradually got used to having at most a cup of rice.
sn3.13:6.1.comm: Nālikā was a cup made from a hollow bamboo. It was a modest meal for a king (SN 22.96:4.10, DN 17:2.15.10), sufficient for a medium-sized mendicant’s bowl (Bi NP 1:2.1.10). It does not appear in this sense in the Arthaśāstra, but the Indian Epigraphical Glossary says it is one-sixteenth of a doṇa and equivalent to a prastha. Olivelle estimates the prastha at around 600g, which is indeed one sixteenth of a doṇa. Bear in mind that rice constituted the bulk of the meal, and for monastics, it would often have been the only meal of the day.

sn3.13:6.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo aparena samayena susallikhitagatto pāṇinā gattāni anumajjanto tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn3.13:6.2.eng: After some time King Pasenadi’s body slimmed right down. Stroking his limbs with his hands, at that time he expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
sn3.13:6.2.comm: Interesting use of sallikhati = sallekha (“cut down” = “slimmed”), related to the idea of “effacing” writing as the stone wears away. For the Jains, sallekhanā was the practice of refusing all food at the end of life (Tattvārthasūtra 7.22; compare the Buddhist practice at MN 8:4.3).

sn3.13:6.3.pli: “ubhayena vata maṃ so bhagavā atthena anukampi—
sn3.13:6.3.eng: “In both ways the Buddha has sympathy for me:

sn3.13:6.4.eng: in the good of this life and the good of the next.”

sn3.14:1.2.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ abbhuyyāsi yena kāsi.
sn3.14:1.2.eng: Then King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kāsi to attack King Pasenadi of Kosala.
sn3.14:1.2.comm: This was obviously after Ajātasattu’s regicide of his father Bimbisāra, and must therefore be in the last years of the Buddha’s life. It is just one of the indications of Ajātasattu’s aggressive nature and the breakdown of peace in the Buddha’s final years. | Kāsi, of which Varanasi was the capital, had lost its status as an independent kingdom to Pasenadi’s father. Here it has become the proxy for the struggle for dominance between the two largest kingdoms of the time, Kosala and Magadha, a struggle that Magadha would ultimately win. | The four divisions of the army are defined in the next Sutta (SN 3.15:1.9).

sn3.14:1.3.eng: When King Pasenadi heard of this,

sn3.14:1.4.pli: “rājā kira māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā mamaṃ abbhuyyāto yena kāsī”ti.

sn3.14:1.5.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ paccuyyāsi yena kāsi.
sn3.14:1.5.eng: he mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kāsi to defend it against Ajātasattu.

sn3.14:1.6.pli: Atha kho rājā ca māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto rājā ca pasenadi kosalo saṅgāmesuṃ.
sn3.14:1.6.eng: Then the two kings met in battle.

sn3.14:1.7.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana saṅgāme rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ parājesi.
sn3.14:1.7.eng: And in that battle Ajātasattu defeated Pasenadi,

sn3.14:1.8.pli: Parājito ca rājā pasenadi kosalo sakameva rājadhāniṃ sāvatthiṃ paccuyyāsi.
sn3.14:1.8.eng: who withdrew to his own capital at Sāvatthī.

sn3.14:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pavisiṃsu.
sn3.14:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

sn3.14:2.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn3.14:2.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then the Buddha said:

sn3.14:3.1.pli: “Idha, bhante, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ abbhuyyāsi yena kāsi.

sn3.14:3.2.pli: Assosi kho, bhante, rājā pasenadi kosalo:

sn3.14:3.3.pli: ‘rājā kira māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā mamaṃ abbhuyyāto yena kāsī’ti.

sn3.14:3.4.pli: Atha kho, bhante, rājā pasenadi kosalo caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ paccuyyāsi yena kāsi.

sn3.14:3.5.pli: Atha kho, bhante, rājā ca māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto rājā ca pasenadi kosalo saṅgāmesuṃ.

sn3.14:3.6.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhante, saṅgāme rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ parājesi.

sn3.14:3.7.pli: Parājito ca, bhante, rājā pasenadi kosalo sakameva rājadhāniṃ sāvatthiṃ paccuyyāsī”ti.

sn3.14:4.1.pli: “Rājā, bhikkhave, māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pāpamitto pāpasahāyo pāpasampavaṅko;
sn3.14:4.1.eng: “Mendicants, King Ajātasattu has bad friends, companions, and associates.
sn3.14:4.1.comm: One of his bad friends was Devadatta.

sn3.14:4.2.pli: rājā ca kho, bhikkhave, pasenadi kosalo kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
sn3.14:4.2.eng: But King Pasenadi has good friends, companions, and associates.
sn3.14:4.2.comm: The Buddha taught Pasenadi the value of good friends at SN 3.18.

sn3.14:4.3.pli: Ajjeva, bhikkhave, rājā pasenadi kosalo imaṃ rattiṃ dukkhaṃ seti parājito”ti.
sn3.14:4.3.eng: Yet on this day King Pasenadi will have a bad night’s sleep as one defeated.”

sn3.14:4.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.14:5.4.eng: having left victory and defeat behind.”

sn3.15:1.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ abbhuyyāsi yena kāsi.
sn3.15:1.1.eng: Then King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kāsi to attack King Pasenadi of Kosala.

sn3.15:1.2.eng: When King Pasenadi heard of this,

sn3.15:1.3.pli: “rājā kira māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā mamaṃ abbhuyyāto yena kāsī”ti.

sn3.15:1.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ paccuyyāsi yena kāsi.
sn3.15:1.4.eng: he mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kāsi to defend it against Ajātasattu.

sn3.15:1.5.pli: Atha kho rājā ca māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto rājā ca pasenadi kosalo saṅgāmesuṃ.
sn3.15:1.5.eng: Then the two kings met in battle.

sn3.15:1.6.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana saṅgāme rājā pasenadi kosalo rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ parājesi, jīvaggāhañca naṃ aggahesi.
sn3.15:1.6.eng: And in that battle Pasenadi defeated Ajātasattu and captured him alive.

sn3.15:1.7.pli: Atha kho rañño pasenadissa kosalassa etadahosi:

sn3.15:1.8.pli: “kiñcāpi kho myāyaṃ rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto adubbhantassa dubbhati, atha ca pana me bhāgineyyo hoti.
sn3.15:1.8.eng: “Even though I’ve never betrayed this King Ajātasattu, he betrayed me. Still, he is my nephew.
sn3.15:1.8.comm: The background is explained in Ja 239. Pasenadi’s father, Mahākosala, had forged an alliance by marrying his daughter to Bimbisāra, endowing her with the revenues of a Kāsi village. Ajātasattu gained the throne by murdering his father, and the queen—Pasenadi’s sister Kosaladevī—died of grief soon after. So when he claimed the village, Pasenadi was outraged at the thought of his father’s gift going to such a man. He took the village, and the series of back-and-forth battles began.

sn3.15:1.9.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ rañño māgadhassa ajātasattuno vedehiputtassa sabbaṃ hatthikāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ assakāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ rathakāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ pattikāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā jīvantameva naṃ osajjeyyan”ti.
sn3.15:1.9.eng: Now that I’ve vanquished all of Ajātasattu’s elephant troops, cavalry, chariots, and infantry, why don’t I let him loose with just his life?”

sn3.15:2.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo rañño māgadhassa ajātasattuno vedehiputtassa sabbaṃ hatthikāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ assakāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ rathakāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ pattikāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā jīvantameva naṃ osajji.

sn3.15:3.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pavisiṃsu.

sn3.15:3.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn3.15:3.2.eng: told the Buddha what had happened.

sn3.15:4.1.pli: “Idha, bhante, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ abbhuyyāsi yena kāsi.

sn3.15:4.2.pli: Assosi kho, bhante, rājā pasenadi kosalo:

sn3.15:4.3.pli: ‘rājā kira māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā mamaṃ abbhuyyāto yena kāsī’ti.

sn3.15:4.4.pli: Atha kho, bhante, rājā pasenadi kosalo caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ paccuyyāsi yena kāsi.

sn3.15:4.5.pli: Atha kho, bhante, rājā ca māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto rājā ca pasenadi kosalo saṅgāmesuṃ.

sn3.15:4.6.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhante, saṅgāme rājā pasenadi kosalo rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ parājesi, jīvaggāhañca naṃ aggahesi.

sn3.15:4.7.pli: Atha kho, bhante, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa etadahosi:

sn3.15:4.8.pli: ‘kiñcāpi kho myāyaṃ rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto adubbhantassa dubbhati, atha ca pana me bhāgineyyo hoti.

sn3.15:4.9.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ rañño māgadhassa ajātasattuno vedehiputtassa sabbaṃ hatthikāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ assakāyaṃ sabbaṃ rathakāyaṃ sabbaṃ pattikāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā jīvantameva naṃ osajjeyyan’”ti.

sn3.15:5.1.pli: “Atha kho, bhante, rājā pasenadi kosalo rañño māgadhassa ajātasattuno vedehiputtassa sabbaṃ hatthikāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ assakāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ rathakāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā sabbaṃ pattikāyaṃ pariyādiyitvā jīvantameva naṃ osajjī”ti.

sn3.15:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn3.15:6.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:

sn3.15:7.2.eng: as long as it serves his ends.

sn3.15:7.3.eng: But as soon as others plunder him,

sn3.15:7.4.comm: See Bodhi’s Connected Discourses, note 263 for this line.

sn3.15:8.1.eng: For the fool thinks they’re on solid ground,
sn3.15:8.1.comm: The idiom here is tricky. Bodhi has, “The fool thinks fortune is on his side”. The commentary glosses ṭhāna with kāraṇa (“reason”). I think ṭhāna (“solid ground”) here sets up the “fall” at the end of the verse.

sn3.15:8.2.eng: so long as their wickedness has not ripened.

sn3.15:8.3.eng: But as soon as that wickedness ripens,

sn3.15:9.1.comm: The Buddha speaks of the tendency for evil conduct to be passed down through generations, a fate that was to befall Ajātasattu himself.

sn3.15:9.4.eng: and a bully creates a bully.

sn3.16:1.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn3.16:1.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

sn3.16:1.3.pli: Atha kho aññataro puriso yena rājā pasenadi kosalo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa upakaṇṇake ārocesi:
sn3.16:1.3.eng: Then a man went up to the king and whispered in his ear,

sn3.16:1.4.eng: “Your Majesty, Queen Mallikā has given birth to a daughter.”

sn3.16:1.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā pasenadi kosalo anattamano ahosi.
sn3.16:1.5.eng: When this was said, King Pasenadi was disappointed.
sn3.16:1.5.comm: He had hoped for a son. The girl was probably princess Vajirī, for whom the king expresses his love at MN 87:24.1. This event must have been several years before the war between Kosala and Magadha, for the commentaries say she was married to Ajātasattu upon cessation of hostilities.

sn3.16:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ anattamanataṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn3.16:2.1.eng: Then, knowing that King Pasenadi was disappointed, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:

sn3.16:3.1.eng: “Well, some women are better than men,

sn3.16:3.2.comm: Read posā, which the commentary glosses posehi, i.e. ablative plural in comparative sense, “than men”.

sn3.16:3.3.eng: Wise and virtuous, a devoted wife
sn3.16:3.3.comm: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.17 gives a rite for those who wish to have a daughter who lives a full life and is an astute scholar (paṇḍitā).

sn3.16:3.4.comm: The compound sassudeva is attributive, “(she who has) mother-in-law as queen”. There is a subtle intertextual tragedy here, for her future mother-in-law was her aunt, who died because of the actions of her future husband Ajātasattu.

sn3.16:4.1.eng: And when she has a son,

sn3.16:4.2.eng: he becomes a hero, O lord of the land.

sn3.16:4.3.eng: The son of such a blessed lady

sn3.16:4.4.comm: According to tradition this did turn out to be the case, as her son with Ajātasattu was Udāyibhadda, fondly recalled by the king at DN 2:12.3. But like his father, he ascended the throne by regicide (Mahāvaṁsa 4.1).

sn3.17:1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.17:1.3.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.17:1.4.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhante, eko dhammo yo ubho atthe samadhiggayha tiṭṭhati—
sn3.17:1.4.eng: “Sir, is there one thing that secures benefits for both
sn3.17:1.4.comm: This discourse is similar to AN 6.53.

sn3.17:1.5.eng: this life and lives to come?”

sn3.17:2.1.pli: “Atthi kho, mahārāja, eko dhammo yo ubho atthe samadhiggayha tiṭṭhati—

sn3.17:3.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, eko dhammo, yo ubho atthe samadhiggayha tiṭṭhati—

sn3.17:4.1.pli: “Appamādo kho, mahārāja, eko dhammo, yo ubho atthe samadhiggayha tiṭṭhati—
sn3.17:4.1.eng: “Diligence, great king, is one thing that secures benefits for both

sn3.17:4.2.eng: this life and lives to come.

sn3.17:4.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, yāni kānici jaṅgalānaṃ pāṇānaṃ padajātāni, sabbāni tāni hatthipade samodhānaṃ gacchanti, hatthipadaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati—yadidaṃ mahantattena;
sn3.17:4.3.eng: The footprints of all creatures that walk can fit inside an elephant’s footprint. So an elephant’s footprint is said to be the biggest of them all.

sn3.17:4.4.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, appamādo eko dhammo, yo ubho atthe samadhiggayha tiṭṭhati—
sn3.17:4.4.eng: In the same way, diligence is one thing that secures benefits for both

sn3.17:4.5.eng: this life and lives to come.”

sn3.17:4.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.17:5.1.comm: These verses are also at AN 5.43:9.1.

sn3.17:7.3.eng: An attentive one, comprehending the meaning,

sn3.18:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.18:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.18:1.3.pli: “idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn3.18:1.3.eng: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.

sn3.18:1.4.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, so ca kho kalyāṇamittassa kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa, no pāpamittassa no pāpasahāyassa no pāpasampavaṅkassā’”ti.
sn3.18:1.4.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha. But it’s for someone with good friends, companions, and associates, not for someone with bad friends, companions, and associates.’”

sn3.18:2.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!” said the Buddha. And he repeated the king’s statement, adding:

sn3.18:2.2.pli: Svākkhāto, mahārāja, mayā dhammo. So ca kho kalyāṇamittassa kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa, no pāpamittassa no pāpasahāyassa no pāpasampavaṅkassāti.

sn3.18:3.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, mahārāja, samayaṃ sakkesu viharāmi nagarakaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo.
sn3.18:3.1.eng: “Great king, this one time I was staying in the land of the Sakyans where they have a town named Townsville.
sn3.18:3.1.comm: “Townsville” is a literal rendering of nagaraka. I translate it in homage to the town in northern Queensland where a chance encounter with a joey set me on the path to the Dhamma. The event the Buddha refers to here is recorded at SN 45.2.

sn3.18:3.2.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ānando bhikkhu yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho, mahārāja, ānando bhikkhu maṃ etadavoca:
sn3.18:3.2.eng: Then the mendicant Ānanda came to me, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:

sn3.18:3.3.eng: ‘Sir, good friends, companions, and associates are half the spiritual life.’

sn3.18:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, mahārāja, ānandaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavocaṃ:
sn3.18:4.1.eng: When he had spoken, I said to him:

sn3.18:4.3.pli: Sakalameva hidaṃ, ānanda, brahmacariyaṃ—yadidaṃ kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.
sn3.18:4.3.eng: Good friends, companions, and associates are the whole of the spiritual life.

sn3.18:4.4.pli: Kalyāṇamittassetaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvessati ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarissati.
sn3.18:4.4.eng: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

sn3.18:5.1.pli: Kathañca, ānanda, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti?
sn3.18:5.1.eng: And how does a mendicant with good friends develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

sn3.18:5.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ, sammāsaṅkappaṃ bhāveti … sammāvācaṃ bhāveti … sammākammantaṃ bhāveti … sammāājīvaṃ bhāveti … sammāvāyāmaṃ bhāveti … sammāsatiṃ bhāveti … sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn3.18:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn3.18:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti.
sn3.18:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant with good friends develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.

sn3.18:5.4.pli: Tadamināpetaṃ, ānanda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sakalamevidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ—yadidaṃ kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatāti.
sn3.18:5.4.eng: And here’s another way to understand how good friends are the whole of the spiritual life.

sn3.18:6.1.pli: Mamañhi, ānanda, kalyāṇamittaṃ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, byādhidhammā sattā byādhito parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti.
sn3.18:6.1.eng: For, by relying on me as a good friend, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.

sn3.18:6.2.pli: Iminā kho etaṃ, ānanda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sakalamevidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ—yadidaṃ kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā’ti.
sn3.18:6.2.eng: This is another way to understand how good friends are the whole of the spiritual life.’

sn3.18:7.1.eng: So, great king, you should train like this:

sn3.18:7.2.eng: ‘I will have good friends, companions, and associates.’

sn3.18:8.1.pli: Kalyāṇamittassa te, mahārāja, kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa ayaṃ eko dhammo upanissāya vihātabbo—
sn3.18:8.1.eng: When you have good friends, companions, and associates, you should live supported by one thing:

sn3.18:9.1.pli: Appamattassa te, mahārāja, viharato appamādaṃ upanissāya, itthāgārassa anuyantassa evaṃ bhavissati:
sn3.18:9.1.eng: When you’re diligent, supported by diligence, your ladies of the harem,

sn3.18:9.3.pli: Handa mayampi appamattā viharāma, appamādaṃ upanissāyā’ti.

sn3.18:10.1.pli: Appamattassa te, mahārāja, viharato appamādaṃ upanissāya, khattiyānampi anuyantānaṃ evaṃ bhavissati:

sn3.18:10.3.pli: Handa mayampi appamattā viharāma, appamādaṃ upanissāyā’ti.

sn3.18:11.1.pli: Appamattassa te, mahārāja, viharato appamādaṃ upanissāya, balakāyassapi evaṃ bhavissati:

sn3.18:11.3.pli: Handa mayampi appamattā viharāma, appamādaṃ upanissāyā’ti.

sn3.18:12.1.pli: Appamattassa te, mahārāja, viharato appamādaṃ upanissāya, negamajānapadassapi evaṃ bhavissati:
sn3.18:12.1.eng: and people of town and country will think:

sn3.18:12.2.eng: ‘The king lives diligently, supported by diligence.

sn3.18:12.3.pli: Handa mayampi appamattā viharāma, appamādaṃ upanissāyā’ti?
sn3.18:12.3.eng: We’d better live diligently, supported by diligence!’

sn3.18:13.1.pli: Appamattassa te, mahārāja, viharato appamādaṃ upanissāya, attāpi gutto rakkhito bhavissati—
sn3.18:13.1.eng: When you’re diligent, supported by diligence, then not only you yourself,

sn3.18:13.2.pli: itthāgārampi guttaṃ rakkhitaṃ bhavissati, kosakoṭṭhāgārampi guttaṃ rakkhitaṃ bhavissatī”ti.
sn3.18:13.2.eng: but your ladies of the harem, and your treasury and storehouses will be guarded and protected.”

sn3.18:13.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.18:15.4.eng: they are said to be astute.”
